citation.article-title: Transfer of Halomonas canadensis and Halomonas israelensis to the genus Chromohalobacter as Chromohalobacter canadensis comb. nov. and Chromohalobacter israelensis comb. nov.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Emended description of the genus Chromohalobacter (Ventosa et al. 1989) Arahal et al.

Cells are Gram-negative, straight or sometimes slightly curved, motile rods that are 0.6-1.2x1.5-4.2 μm and occur singly, in pairs and in short chains. Non-sporeforming. Colonies are pigmented cream to brown-yellow. Moderate halophiles. Salt is required for growth. Optimal growth occurs in the presence of 8-10%(w/v) salt. May grow at salt concentrations up to 30%(w/v). The broader ranges of temperature and pH observed for growth are 5-45 °C and pH 5.0-10.0. Chemo-organotrophs. Aerobic. Catalase-positive. Most strains reduce nitrate, but H2S is not produced. Negative for urease and phenylalanine deaminase. Casein, DNA, aesculin, gelatin, starch and Tween 80 are not hydrolysed. Acid is produced from arabinose, glucose, glycerol, lactose and xylose. Habitat: the Dead Sea and marine salterns. The DNA base composition ranges from 62 to 65 mol%, as determined by the thermal denaturation method. The type species is Chromohalobacter marismortui.
